title: China donates supplies to 'Chinese Corner' in Malian National Library
description: On April 2, 2015, a ceremony was held for the completion of the "Chinese Corner" in the Malian National Library. The "Chinese Corner" project was established by the Hanban of China in cooperation with the National Library of Mali. The Chinese Corner is a space dedicated to the study of Chinese culture and language. The Chinese government donated 300 books and posters, and $8,000 for the purchase of furniture, for the "Chinese Corner."    The total cost of the project is unknown, so the transaction amount has been coded to only include the $8,000 donated to purchase furniture.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China donates supplies to 'Chinese Corner' in Malian National Library

# Description
On April 2, 2015, a ceremony was held for the completion of the "Chinese Corner" in the Malian National Library. The "Chinese Corner" project was established by the Hanban of China in cooperation with the National Library of Mali. The Chinese Corner is a space dedicated to the study of Chinese culture and language. The Chinese government donated 300 books and posters, and $8,000 for the purchase of furniture, for the "Chinese Corner."    The total cost of the project is unknown, so the transaction amount has been coded to only include the $8,000 donated to purchase furniture.
justification: Project focuses on cultural and educational exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of books and furniture for cultural education space, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government dispatches 24th medical team to Mali Hospital
description: Since 1968, Zhejiang Province has been sending medical teams to Mali every 2 years. On January 29, 2015, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mali signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 24th Chinese medical team to Mali. The 31-member team was stationed at the Mali Hospital (Hôpital du Mali or 3ème centre hospitalier de référence), which is located on the right bank of the Niger River in Yirimadio within Commune 6 and Bamako District.    The team completed its term of service between July 21, 2015 and July 26, 2017. In June 2016, the team visited Sikasso Hospital and completed a total of 918 outpatient visits, 45 CT scans, 62 ultrasounds, 41 examinations. Additionally, the team performed super-large ovarian cyst resection, baby cleft lip repair, pediatric brain swelling repair, and 28 operations such as nodular goiter, salivary gland tumor resection, and uterine myomectomy.
staff_comments: - The 24th medical team was the third Chinese medical team to be stationed at the newly-constructed Mali Hospital, which was financed with a Chinese Government grant (captured in Project ID#1505).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 24th medical team to Mali Hospital

# Description
Since 1968, Zhejiang Province has been sending medical teams to Mali every 2 years. On January 29, 2015, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mali signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 24th Chinese medical team to Mali. The 31-member team was stationed at the Mali Hospital (Hôpital du Mali or 3ème centre hospitalier de référence), which is located on the right bank of the Niger River in Yirimadio within Commune 6 and Bamako District.    The team completed its term of service between July 21, 2015 and July 26, 2017. In June 2016, the team visited Sikasso Hospital and completed a total of 918 outpatient visits, 45 CT scans, 62 ultrasounds, 41 examinations. Additionally, the team performed super-large ovarian cyst resection, baby cleft lip repair, pediatric brain swelling repair, and 28 operations such as nodular goiter, salivary gland tumor resection, and uterine myomectomy.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare services provided, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Embassy donates to the Bamako Orphanage in Mali
description: On December 21, 2015, the Chinese Embassy in Mali donated to the orphanage in Bamako. Chinese Ambassador Lu Huiying and Ms. Sangare Umm Ba, the Malian Minister of the Ministry of Women, Children and Family Promotion of Malaysia, attended the donation ceremony. The value of the donation is unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates to the Bamako Orphanage in Mali

# Description
On December 21, 2015, the Chinese Embassy in Mali donated to the orphanage in Bamako. Chinese Ambassador Lu Huiying and Ms. Sangare Umm Ba, the Malian Minister of the Ministry of Women, Children and Family Promotion of Malaysia, attended the donation ceremony. The value of the donation is unclear.
justification: Project is a social development initiative with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation to orphanage, social welfare focus, no energy or infrastructure components mentioned

title: China donates to Action for the Promotion and Development of Women in Mali
description: On October 17, 2015, the Chinese embassy in Mali donated an electric classroom to Mali's Women's Organization, Action for the Promotion and Development of Women ("行动"). Mali's Minister of Women, Minister of Vocational Training, Minister of National Education, Minister of Culture, and Secretary-General of the Presidential Office attended the ceremony.  Chinese Ambassador Lu Huiying delivered a speech at the ceremony.    The total cost of the project and start and end dates are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates to Action for the Promotion and Development of Women in Mali

# Description
On October 17, 2015, the Chinese embassy in Mali donated an electric classroom to Mali's Women's Organization, Action for the Promotion and Development of Women ("行动"). Mali's Minister of Women, Minister of Vocational Training, Minister of National Education, Minister of Culture, and Secretary-General of the Presidential Office attended the ceremony.  Chinese Ambassador Lu Huiying delivered a speech at the ceremony.    The total cost of the project and start and end dates are unknown.
justification: Project focuses on social development and education without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of electric classroom to women's organization, attended by government officials from education and culture sectors

title: China provides 52 scholarships to Malian students to study in China
description: On August 28, 2015, the Chinese Embassy in Mali held a ceremony for the 52 Malian students receiving Chinese scholarships to study in China. It is unclear for how long the Malian students would study in China for. The total cost of this project is unclear.
combined_text:

EDUCATION

# Title
China provides 52 scholarships to Malian students to study in China

On August 28, 2015, the Chinese Embassy in Mali held a ceremony for the 52 Malian students receiving Chinese scholarships to study in China. It is unclear for how long the Malian students would study in China for. The total cost of this project is unclear.
justification: Project focuses on education and human development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarships for Malian students to study in China, education sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides an aid package to Mali
description: On April 20, 2015, the Chinese Government handed over an aid package, which included a vehicle, to the Government of Mali, in the presence of the President of Mali Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta and other senior Malian officials. The value of this aid, as well as of its components, is unknown.
staff_comments: The presence of what appears to be motorcycles in '我援马里物资举行交接仪式' suggests that they may have been part of this aid package.
combined_text:
# Sector
UNALLOCATED/UNSPECIFIED

# Title
Chinese Government provides an aid package to Mali

# Description
On April 20, 2015, the Chinese Government handed over an aid package, which included a vehicle, to the Government of Mali, in the presence of the President of Mali Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta and other senior Malian officials. The value of this aid, as well as of its components, is unknown.
justification: Aid package with unspecified components, no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: General aid package including a vehicle, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese medical team visits University of Bamako Kabbala campus to provide physical examinations on workers
description: On March 29, 2015, the Chinese medical team in Mali visited the University of Bamako Kabbala campus construction site and provided medical exams for the workers there. This project is being captured because it is unclear if the workers on this project were only Chinese or if there were also local Malian workers who received examinations.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese medical team visits University of Bamako Kabbala campus to provide physical examinations on workers

# Description
On March 29, 2015, the Chinese medical team in Mali visited the University of Bamako Kabbala campus construction site and provided medical exams for the workers there. This project is being captured because it is unclear if the workers on this project were only Chinese or if there were also local Malian workers who received examinations.
justification: Project involves healthcare services with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team providing physical examinations at university campus construction site

title: China Eximbank contributes to first tranche of $227.5 million syndicated loan to Star Bulk Carriers for construction of seven vessels (Linked to Project ID#66250, #63094, #63138, #63139, #63140, #63201, #63203)
description: On March 31, 2015, the Star Bulk Carriers Corp, a shipping company organized under the laws of the Republic of Marshall Islands, entered into an agreement with DNB Bank ASA as facility agent, security agent account bank, and book runner, DNB Bank ASA and the Export-Import Bank of China (CEXIM) as mandated lead arrangers and DNB Bank ASA, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB (SEB) and CEXIM as original lenders (the “DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227.5 million Facility”) for up to $227.5 million to partially finance the construction cost of seven new building vessels, Gargantua (ex-HN166), Goliath (ex-HN167), Maharaj (ex-HN184), Star Poseidon (ex-HN198), Star Aries (ex-HN1338), Star Taurus (ex-HN1339), and Star Eleni (HN1342). The financing is available in seven separate tranches, one for each new vessel. This Project ID#62802 records the first tranche of $32.4 million for financing the construction of Gargantua (ex-HN166). However, China Exim Bank's specific contribution to this tranche is unknown. Project ID#66250 records all seven tranches and total Chinese official financial commitments.   As a result of the sale of the Star Aries and the Star Taurus, Star Bulk Carriers Corp. decided not to draw down on two tranches under this facility. The first tranche of $32.4 million and the second and third tranches of $30.3 million each were drawn upon the delivery of the vessels Gargantua on April 15, 2015, and Goliath and Maharaj on July 15, 2015. The fourth tranche of $23.4 million was drawn, upon the delivery of the vessel Star Poseidon on February 16, 2016. On June 29, 2015, Star Bulks signed a supplemental letter with the lenders under this facility to amend certain covenants governing this facility until December 31, 2016, that as a result of the sale of the Star Aries on February 29, 2016, and that of the Star Taurus on April 16, 2016, the lenders will not draw down on the fifth and the sixth tranches under this facility. In 2017 the recipient canceled the loan commitment for Star Eleni, the seventh tranche, that on January 3, 2018, the recipient took delivery of the Newcastlemax vessels Star Eleni (ex HN 1342) which was financed under bareboat leases with CSSC.  The tranches are repayable in 24 quarterly consecutive installments ranging between $0.4 million and $0.5 million, with the first becoming due and payable three months from the draw-down date of each tranche and a final balloon installment for each tranche, ranging between $14.6 million and $20.2 million payable simultaneously with the 24th installment. The DNB–SEB–CEXIM $227.5 million Facility was secured by a first priority cross-collateralized mortgage over the financed vessels and general and specific assignments and is guaranteed by Star Bulk Carriers Corp. The delivery installments of $113,046 in aggregate for the respective vessels were partially financed by $93,000 drawn down under the DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227,500 Facility.  On September 27, 2018, Star Bulks entered into a loan agreement with DNB Bank ASA for a loan of $310.0 million, a tranche of $240 million of which refinanced all amounts outstanding under multiple facilities including the DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227.5 million facility. The $240 million was drawn on September 28, 2018 and will be repayable in 20 equal quarterly installments of $8.7 million and a balloon payment along with the last installment in an amount of $66.1 million. The tranche of $70 million will be repayable in 12 quarterly installments, each being equal to 5.55% of that tranche and the remaining balance will be repaid in the form of a balloon installment at the final repayment date.
staff_comments: 1.  Project ID#66250 records all seven tranches and total Chinese official financial commitments.2. AidData has coded this transaction as a collateralized loan because DNB Bank ASA was selected as the security agent (i.e. collateral agent) for the loan. When lenders take collateral as security for their loans, a collateral/security agent is often appointed to enforce rights against the collateral in the event of the borrower’s default under the loan.3. Star Bulk Carriers Corp is a Marshall Islands-incorporated shipping company. It owns and operates a fleet of dry bulk carrier vessels. The Company's vessels transport major bulks, which include iron ore, coal and grain, and minor bulks, which include bauxite, fertilizers and steel products.4. This project is linked to Project ID#62802 (first tranche), ID#63094 (second tranche), ID#63138 (third tranche), ID#63139 (fourth tranche), ID#63140 (fifth tranche), ID#63201 (sixth tranche), and ID#63203 (seventh tranche).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title

The financing is available in seven separate tranches, one for each new vessel. This Project ID#62802 records the first tranche of $32.4 million for financing the construction of Gargantua (ex-HN166). However, China Exim Bank's specific contribution to this tranche is unknown. Project ID#66250 records all seven tranches and total Chinese official financial commitments.   As a result of the sale of the Star Aries and the Star Taurus, Star Bulk Carriers Corp. decided not to draw down on two tranches under this facility. The first tranche of $32.4 million and the second and third tranches of $30.3 million each were drawn upon the delivery of the vessels Gargantua on April 15, 2015, and Goliath and Maharaj on July 15, 2015. The fourth tranche of $23.4 million was drawn, upon the delivery of the vessel Star Poseidon on February 16, 2016. On June 29, 2015, Star Bulks signed a supplemental letter with the lenders under this facility to amend certain covenants governing this facility until December 31, 2016, that as a result of the sale of the Star Aries on February 29, 2016, and that of the Star Taurus on April 16, 2016, the lenders will not draw down on the fifth and the sixth tranches under this facility. In 2017 the recipient canceled the loan commitment for Star Eleni, the seventh tranche, that on January 3, 2018, the recipient took delivery of the Newcastlemax vessels Star Eleni (ex HN 1342) which was financed under bareboat leases with CSSC.  The tranches are repayable in 24 quarterly consecutive installments ranging between $0.4 million and $0.5 million, with the first becoming due and payable three months from the draw-down date of each tranche and a final balloon installment for each tranche, ranging between $14.6 million and $20.2 million payable simultaneously with the 24th installment. The DNB–SEB–CEXIM $227.5 million Facility was secured by a first priority cross-collateralized mortgage over the financed vessels and general and specific assignments and is guaranteed by Star Bulk Carriers Corp. The delivery installments of $113,046 in aggregate for the respective vessels were partially financed by $93,000 drawn down under the DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227,500 Facility.  On September 27, 2018, Star Bulks entered into a loan agreement with DNB Bank ASA for a loan of $310.0 million, a tranche of $240 million of which refinanced all amounts outstanding under multiple facilities including the DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227.5 million facility. The $240 million was drawn on September 28, 2018 and will be repayable in 20 equal quarterly installments of $8.7 million and a balloon payment along with the last installment in an amount of $66.1 million. The tranche of $70 million will be repayable in 12 quarterly installments, each being equal to 5.55% of that tranche and the remaining balance will be repaid in the form of a balloon installment at the final repayment date.
justification: Project involves financing for construction of commercial vessels without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Financing for construction of seven new vessels, no specific environmental or energy transition focus mentioned

China Eximbank contributes to third tranche of $227.5 million syndicated loan to Star Bulk Carriers for construction of seven vessels (Linked to Project ID#66250, #62802, #63094, #63139, #63140, #63201, #63203)

# Description
On March 31, 2015, Star Bulk Carriers Corp., a shipping company organized under the laws of the Republic of Marshall Islands, entered into an agreement with DNB Bank ASA as facility agent, security agent account bank, and book runner, DNB Bank ASA and the Export-Import Bank of China (CEXIM) as mandated lead arrangers and DNB Bank ASA, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB (SEB) and CEXIM as original lenders (the “DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227.5 million Facility”) for up to $227.5 million to partially finance the construction cost of seven new building vessels, Gargantua (ex-HN166), Goliath (ex-HN167), Maharaj (ex-HN184), Star Poseidon (ex-HN198), Star Aries (ex-HN1338), Star Taurus (ex-HN1339), and Star Eleni (HN1342). The financing is available in seven separate tranches, one for each new vessel. This Project ID#63138 records the third tranche of $30.3 million for the financing of Maharaj (ex-HN184). However, China Exim Bank's specific contribution to this tranche is unknown. Project ID#66250 records all seven tranches and total Chinese official financial commitments.  As a result of the sale of the Star Aries and the Star Taurus, Star Bulk Carriers Corp. decided not to draw down on two tranches under this facility. The first tranche of $32.4 million and the second and third tranches of $30.3 million each were drawn upon the delivery of the vessels Gargantua on April 15, 2015, and Goliath and Maharaj on July 15, 2015. The fourth tranche of $23.4 million was drawn, upon the delivery of the vessel Star Poseidon on February 16, 2016. On June 29, 2015, Star Bulks signed a supplemental letter with the lenders under this facility to amend certain covenants governing this facility until December 31, 2016, that as a result of the sale of the Star Aries on February 29, 2016, and that of the Star Taurus on April 16, 2016, the lenders will not draw down on the fifth and the sixth tranches under this facility. In 2017 the recipient canceled the loan commitment for Star Eleni, the seventh tranche, that on January 3, 2018, the recipient took delivery of the Newcastlemax vessels Star Eleni (ex HN 1342) which was financed under bareboat leases with CSSC.  The tranches are repayable in 24 quarterly consecutive installments ranging between $0.4 million and $0.5 million, with the first becoming due and payable three months from the draw-down date of each tranche and a final balloon installment for each tranche, ranging between $14.6 million and $20.2 million payable simultaneously with the 24th installment. The DNB–SEB–CEXIM $227.5 million Facility was secured by a first priority cross-collateralized mortgage over the financed vessels and general and specific assignments and is guaranteed by Star Bulk Carriers Corp. The delivery installments of $113,046 in aggregate for the respective vessels were partially financed by $93,000 drawn down under the DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227,500 Facility.  On September 27, 2018, Star Bulks entered into a loan agreement with DNB Bank ASA for a loan of $310 million, a tranche of $240 million of which refinanced all amounts outstanding under multiple facilities including the DNB-SEB-CEXIM $227.5 million facility. The $240 million was drawn on September 28, 2018, and will be repayable in 20 equal quarterly installments of $8.7 million and a balloon payment along with the last installment in an amount of $66.1 million. The tranche of $70 million will be repayable in 12 quarterly installments, each being equal to 5.55% of that tranche and the remaining balance will be repaid in the form of a balloon installment at the final repayment date.
justification: Project involves financing for construction of commercial vessels without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Financing for construction of seven new building vessels, no specific environmental or energy transition focus mentioned
